content.description: Aptly named. Start up the crack into a corner. Then a flakey crack that flares out into a wide crack that tops onto a dirty ledge with brush. From there, a final shallow stemming corner takes you to the anchors
content.protection: Chain Anchors. Tree Anchor right next to the ledge
content.location: From below look for the #3 sign on the tree, marking the bottom of Orient Express. To the left of the ledge, look for the "Bite" bubble letter graffiti for the startFrom the top, setup a rappel on the chain anchors or tree anchor then move straight down.

content.description: This is a route from the ground up to the top of the Far East halfway ledge. This gets you to the bottom of most of the Far East climbs, such as Orient Express. Climb the left-facing crack to the top of the ledge.Also known as Eye of the Tiger in the Rocky Butte Quarry guidebook. Tiger's Eye is likely a reference to the chatoyant gemstone rather than "Eye of the Tiger" which is a hot single released by American rock band Survivor in 1982.
content.location: This is located just below Orient Express. It has its own rusty chain anchors. From below, look for the #3 sign on the tree. The ledge is behind that tree, which is also the top of the route

content.description: Start with a thin crack and smearing feet. Snag a jug and move up onto the slab. Use holds in the seam and crimps on the right face. The angle steepens in the middle and you have to move onto the face. Finish up a lower angle slab that trends right to the anchors.
content.location: Obvious right-trending bolted seam that starts in front of a hearty fir tree on the main ledge.

content.description: Start just to the left of the left-facing crack below the 1st bolt. Its a slabby face climb without great feet or hand holds. Smearing is essential
content.protection: Set of chain anchors at the top
content.location: From the bottom, look to the right of the shallow dihedral which is Orient Express. You'll see a long of bolts just to the left of a left-facing crack. From the top, look for the fattest tree along the sliffside, which rests on the top of a prow. The next prow to the left should give sight of the top chain anchors

content.description: Starts at a crack to the right of The Wanderer, which is the left side of a large ledge where you would belay for routes like Orient Express. The official climb is very short, basically taking you to the top of the ledge, to the base of Chinese Finger Torture. However, you can take the crack proper all the way by continuing left through High Road to China or right through Chinese Finger Torture.
content.protection: Bolted Chain Anchors. Tree Anchor away 5 feet from the top
content.location: From below look for the #3 sign on the tree, marking the bottom of Orient Express. To the left of the ledge, look for a birch tree next to a faded graffiti tag that says "Hi".From the top, setup a rappel on the chain anchors or tree anchor then move right and down.

content.description: Starts with a slab then gains a right trending crack/flake. Chain anchor below the top ledge or tree above for a TR anchor.
content.protection: Bolt on the slab down low then gear.
content.location: Right trending crack/flake with a tree growing out of the rock above.

content.description: A well-bolted line with a couple of challenging moves on the bulge. Start off on slab and end on slab. Top rope can been set up on the tree at the top or rappel down then lead your way back up.
content.protection: 7 quick draws, bolts are a bit old but they're close together.
content.location: Just left of Orient Express dihedral.

content.description: Start by ascending Great Wall of China, or finding a way to shimmy left from the bottom of Ghost Rider. The crack just runs below the triangular roof feature, below the tree on the ledge above. Make your way up and right of that feature, continuing about all the way to the ledge tree. Once you get to the slightly overhanging face at the base of the tree, at the large horizontal crack, you can traverse leftward or just burl up and over the bulging arete
content.protection: Chain Anchors. Tree Anchor about 5 feet from the top
content.location: From below look for the #3 sign on the tree, marking the bottom of Orient Express. To the left of the ledge, look for the triangular roof feature.From the top, setup a rappel on the chain anchors or tree anchor then move right and down.

content.description: Typical Rocky Butte. Look for the #3 markers to identify the area
